byline.contributor: Matt Furber reported from Brooklyn Center, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York.
byline.original: By MATT FURBER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Federal officials say two white Minneapolis police officers involved in fatal shooting of black man Jamar Clark in 2015 will not face federal charges, as their account of sequence of events seemed to be corroborated by evidence; eyewitness claimed Clark was shot while handcuffed, statement that sparked days of demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: The civil rights of Jamar Clark, a 24-year-old black man, were not violated when two white police officers fatally shot him in November, federal officials said.

headline.main: No Federal Charges for Minneapolis Officers in Fatal Shooting
headline.print_headline: No Federal Charges for Minneapolis Officers in Fatal Shooting of Black Man

snippet: The civil rights of Jamar Clark, a 24-year-old black man, were not violated when two white police officers fatally shot him in November, federal officials said.

keywords.value: Ringgenberg, Mark A (Minneapolis, Minn, Police Officer )
